questions.question: If you wanna shut down the entire economy for a year, you have to pay for it, right?
So if government naturally wants to buy stuff it can't afford, what's the best form of government?
You put the million dollars into gold, gold will sit in a vault for a decade, okay?
And I Google something the other day, what's the most common form of mammal life on Earth?
And so what's the value of giving a million books to eight billion people, right?
And what does that mean for others at the scale that might be doing the same?
Can I actually put enough money in a car for it to drive itself and maintain itself forever?
There's an ethical thing here, which is like what's the right to promote a not?
So the all the things that you're saying that make it a property, can that be replicated?
Because if I had a billion dollar building in Moscow, who can I rent that to?
Are there certain characteristics of any of them that kind of stand out to you?
Like if you said to me, Mike, what should I buy for the next 100 years?
How to have a career they can be proud of, how to have a life they can be proud of?
Do you think there's there's all kinds of journeys you can take to educate yourself?
Or is there other paths through life that is worth it if you have to pay for it?
